segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: The Minimum password length policy setting determines the least number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.
segment.target: The Minimum password length policy setting determines the least number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

segment.source: You can set a value of between 1 and 14 characters, or you can establish that no password is required by setting the number of characters to 0.
segment.target: You can set a value of between 1 and 14 characters, or you can establish that no password is required by setting the number of characters to 0.

segment.target: User-specified number of characters between 0 and 14

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: Set Minimum password length to at least a value of 8.
segment.target: Set Minimum password length to at least a value of 8.

segment.source: If the number of characters is set to 0, no password is required.
segment.target: If the number of characters is set to 0, no password is required.

segment.source: In most environments, an eight-character password is recommended because it is long enough to provide adequate security and still short enough for users to easily remember.
segment.target: In most environments, an eight-character password is recommended because it is long enough to provide adequate security and still short enough for users to easily remember.

segment.source: This value will help provide adequate defense against a brute force attack.
segment.target: This value will help provide adequate defense against a brute force attack.

segment.source: Adding complexity requirements will help reduce the possibility of a dictionary attack.
segment.target: Adding complexity requirements will help reduce the possibility of a dictionary attack.

segment.source: For more info, see Password must meet complexity requirements.
segment.target: For more info, see Password must meet complexity requirements.

segment.source: Permitting short passwords reduces security because short passwords can be easily broken with tools that perform dictionary or brute force attacks against the passwords.
segment.target: Permitting short passwords reduces security because short passwords can be easily broken with tools that perform dictionary or brute force attacks against the passwords.

segment.source: Requiring very long passwords can result in mistyped passwords that might cause an account lockout and subsequently increase the volume of Help Desk calls.
segment.target: Requiring very long passwords can result in mistyped passwords that might cause an account lockout and subsequently increase the volume of Help Desk calls.

segment.source: In addition, requiring extremely long passwords can actually decrease the security of an organization because users might be more likely to write down their passwords to avoid forgetting them.
segment.target: In addition, requiring extremely long passwords can actually decrease the security of an organization because users might be more likely to write down their passwords to avoid forgetting them.

segment.source: However, if users are taught that they can use passphrases (sentences such as "I want to drink a $5 milkshake"), they should be much more likely to remember.
segment.target: However, if users are taught that they can use passphrases (sentences such as "I want to drink a $5 milkshake"), they should be much more likely to remember.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Types of password attacks include dictionary attacks (which attempt to use common words and phrases) and brute force attacks (which try every possible combination of characters).
segment.target: Types of password attacks include dictionary attacks (which attempt to use common words and phrases) and brute force attacks (which try every possible combination of characters).

segment.source: Also, attackers sometimes try to obtain the account database so they can use tools to discover the accounts and passwords.
segment.target: Also, attackers sometimes try to obtain the account database so they can use tools to discover the accounts and passwords.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Configure the **** policy setting to a value of 8 or more.
segment.target: Configure the **** policy setting to a value of 8 or more.

segment.source: If the number of characters is set to 0, no password will be required.
segment.target: If the number of characters is set to 0, no password will be required.

segment.source: In most environments, we recommend an eight-character password because it is long enough to provide adequate security, but not too difficult for users to easily remember.
segment.target: In most environments, we recommend an eight-character password because it is long enough to provide adequate security, but not too difficult for users to easily remember.

segment.source: This configuration provides adequate defense against a brute force attack.
segment.target: This configuration provides adequate defense against a brute force attack.

segment.source: Using the Password must meet complexity requirements policy setting in addition to the Minimum password length setting helps reduce the possibility of a dictionary attack.
segment.target: Using the Password must meet complexity requirements policy setting in addition to the Minimum password length setting helps reduce the possibility of a dictionary attack.

segment.source: Note: Some jurisdictions have established legal requirements for password length as part of establishing security regulations.
segment.target: Note: Some jurisdictions have established legal requirements for password length as part of establishing security regulations.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Requirements for extremely long passwords can actually decrease the security of an organization because users might leave the information in an unsecured location or lose it.
segment.target: Requirements for extremely long passwords can actually decrease the security of an organization because users might leave the information in an unsecured location or lose it.

segment.source: If very long passwords are required, mistyped passwords could cause account lockouts and increase the volume of Help Desk calls.
segment.target: If very long passwords are required, mistyped passwords could cause account lockouts and increase the volume of Help Desk calls.

segment.source: If your organization has issues with forgotten passwords due to password length requirements, consider teaching your users about passphrases, which are often easier to remember and, due to the larger number of character combinations, much harder to discover.
segment.target: If your organization has issues with forgotten passwords due to password length requirements, consider teaching your users about passphrases, which are often easier to remember and, due to the larger number of character combinations, much harder to discover.
